title: Friday, 25th May, 2018

BE11:13am

Royal Mail highlighted the risk from adoption of the GDPR (General Data Protection Regulations) and indicated that the rate of volume decline may be at the upper end of the usual 4-6% range. We think that is likely to prove a “best-case” scenario. Companies are very uncertain about how to comply with GDPR and there is a strong possibility that they will temporarily rein in their marketing activities rather than risk breaching the regulations. We estimate that a 20% reduction in marketing volumes could hit overall mail volumes by an incremental 2%, or about £80m of revenue. Given the high fixed costs in the business, much of that loss would likely drop through to EBIT.

FATDAZ morning all
11:13 am

Plus the increasing push towards Sunday or same-day delivery, thank you Amazon. Royal Mail is unable to do either of these things, probably structurally given unions and whatnot.

On our revised estimates, Royal Mail trades at a small premium
the European peer group on c.14x calendar P/E for 2018E and 2019E, with a dividend yield of 4.6% versus peers on c6%. However, with EBIT margins and EPS growth both below average for the European peer group, we think that a discount to the peer group is justifiable. At our price target, the shares would trade on 12x CY 2019E P/E and a 5.7% dividend yield.

BE11:23am

Assuming that Hilco intends to trade the Homebase brand, rather than engineer a breakup of the chain, we envisage a number of likely changes in the offering. We are unsure of how accretive this will be to customer experience. Critically, Homebase will miss the considerable buying muscle of Bunnings in Asia, and we would expect less aggressive pricing on seasonal products (including barbies) as a result. A number of branded suppliers had strongly backed BUKI in a bid to create an alternative to B&Q in the UK, and that support is likely to soften under the new ownership structure. More generally the extent of operating losses currently suffered by Homebase provides limited room for manoeuvre. We would assume gross margins will have to be lifted (perhaps by reverting back to a hi-lo stance?) and service levels cut back. The scope for incremental cash investments looks very limited, and availability (the one customer metric that had significantly improved under Wesfarmers’ ownership, given a remarkably generous injection of stock) is likely to suffer.

BE11:23am

Ultimately, the risk ahead of today was that Wesfarmers
would be irrational and back a significant investment to rebrand Homebase stores into Bunnings. Today’s news should see B&Q’s biggest competitor (and arguably the only alternative to retail customers in the UK large-sheds DIY market, given Wickes’ squarely more trade oriented offering) become much more sensitive to short, and mid term, margin and cashflow challenges.

BE11:24am

Wesfarmers’ intention to exit from the Homebase business has
been widely known and is partly a reflection of the competitive nature of the UK DIY market and poor consumer sentiment. Although Hilco Capital's intention with the Homebase brand is unclear at this stage, the restructuring most likely would include store closures to manage the cash drain from the business providing opportunity to Wickes among others, to gain market share. Although Wickes has been taking share vs. its peers over the past three years, driven by competitive pricing and stronger service offer, this restructuring could further accelerate the trend into H218. We do not expect consensus estimates to change significantly at this stage; this transaction could help offset any material deterioration in the underlying consumer sentiment in H218 and support FY expectations. Stock trades on a 2018e PE of 12x and EV/EBITDA of 7.4x on our estimates.

We move from an Add to a Buy recommendation with an unchanged target price of 180p based on 1.2x NAV and 10x CF.

Production should move back up in 2019 as mining in the open pit moves back into higher grade material and the ration of development to stope tonnes renormalizes. The shares are currently trading at 0.78x NAV vs the average over the past year of 0.95x.

FATDAZ @WayneJ You have hit the nail on the head .....that is the Winner / Loser

Is 0.78x NAV really so cheap when the company's misfiring operationally and is operating in a historically tricky legal jurisdiction?

BE11:32am

Hm. Here's Morgan Stanley for balance.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

We estimate the impact on EBITDA at roughly $90m or 22% of our FY18 estimate. We thought at the end of 1Q that the company had a lot of work to do, and lower grades from the open pit that continued into 2Q plus equipment availability issues that have impacted underground production have led to the company reducing the guidance. We see this as quite a significant negative for the stock in the short term, but if grades and equipment availability can be resolved, then there is upside into 2019e as Cleopatra comes online. For now we stay on the sidelines and remain Equal-weight.

wayneJ Would it be rational for BT to sell a stake in OpenReach to Deutsche Telekom (who also owns a stake in BT)....
BE11:40am

The Bloomberg article says that BT has pledged to connect 10m UK premises to fibre-to-the-premise by 2025, but in fact it has not pledged this: instead, it has an “ambition” to reach 10m premises by the mid-2020s under the right conditions. The article also repeats the story from last weekend’s Telegraph that BT is looking to sell its mobile towers. However, BT does not own the vast majority of its towers, which are instead rented from companies like Arqiva and WIG by its network management joint venture MBNL (with Three). These errors make us question the accuracy of the story.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

BE11:43am

Anyway, there's also the pension hurdle. Back to Berenberg.

BE11:43am

Against a £20bn market cap, BT’s gross pension liabilities are £57bn and the IAS19 pension deficit at March 2018 was £5.3bn net (£6.4bn gross). Due to Openreach’s scale, age demographics and tenure of its employees, a significant proportion of this relates to Openreach. The strength of covenant provided by the company is very important in determining the deficit repair terms the pension trustees will agree to. Put simply, being part of a bigger, more diversified stream of cash flows makes the trustees more relaxed that future payments can be supported. Whether the deficit was attached to Openreach in any sale or stayed with the remaining group, the strength of the covenant would weaken either way, leading the trustees to ask for more deficit repair payments in the near term (BT has already agreed to £4.5bn of contributions before the next triennial review).

Soundbuy @FATDAZ - ??
FATDAZ @BE is BT among the UK companies that have seen a turn around in pension shortfalls ?
FATDAZ @soundbuy Lloyds HBOS
11:43 am
BE11:44am

Barclays also, while we're here.

BE11:44am

We value Openreach at £13bn, or 5.6x Mar 19e EV/EBITDA and 13.6x EV/EBIT, and c1x EV/RAB. BT has not commented on the report, but has repeatedly indicated (e.g. full year results presentation) that it sees value in being a fully integrated fixed and mobile network operator, with Openreach having the benefit of an “anchor tenant” with which to make the FTTH business model work - Examples of separation are New Zealand and O2 Czech Republic. With BT shares under continued pressure, and our belief that the current regulatory/political climate makes the FTTH business case even harder for BT, we would not be surprised to see this debate run, with full structural separation a potential route out, with BT trading on 9x P/E, 5.4x EV/EBITDA and offering a 9.5% equity FCF yield.

wayneJ "The corporate governance of HBOS at board level serves as a model for the future, but not in the way in which Lord Stevenson and other board members appear to see it. It represents a model of self-delusion, of the triumph of process over purpose". (Parliament's Banking Standards Commission report, issued in April 2013)
BE11:45am

And Jefferies ........

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Whilst informal approaches may have been made, BT is most unlikely to see value in selling off an Openreach stake. We highlight 3 reasons.

BE11:45am

(1) BT has publicly argued that capital is not the factor that limits the pace of its FTTP roll-out. Getting deployment costs down and boosting labour capacity are issues not solved by a change in ownership. (2) Openreach is hard to value whilst the future regulatory framework for its FTTP deployment remains largely undefined and market share looks chronically threatened by AltNet overbuild. (3) Diluting BT's economic interest in its most profitable asset would refocus attention on consumer (where retail BB share is declining) and Enterprise (structurally challenged).

wayneJ I have never understood why Sky has not faced the same scrutiny as BT - surely the Settop box and the transmission service should be regulated. I was once a shareholder in a small channel on Sky - and frankly one felt (delicately putting this) that requirements and pricing for transmission and to appear on the EPG were 'extraordinary'
